column1: There was no place for the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner
column2: and so they made a practice of washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage. There were the butt-ends of smoked meat
column3: and the scraps of corned beef
column4: and all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants
column5: that would be dumped into old barrels in the cellar and left there. Under the system of rigid economy which the packers enforced
column6: there were some jobs that it only paid to do once in a long time
column7: and among these was the cleaning out of the waste barrels. Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water – and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat
column8: and sent out to the public's breakfast. Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time
column10: they would call upon their chemistry department
column11: and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown.
